title.narrative: DRC Internally Displaced Persons phase II

description.narrative: Stöd till statens Strategi och handlingsplan för internflyktingar, med fokus på integration av internflyktingar i det georgiska samhället. Programmet omfattar utveckling av hållbara bostadslösningar, alternativ försörjning, tillhandahållande av rättshjälp och kapacitetsuppbyggnad av MRA. Fas II

Support to the State Strategy and AP on IDPs, focusing on integration of the displaced population into Georgian society. The programme includes development of durable housing solutions, livelihood options, provision of legal aid and capacity building of MRA. Phase II

description.narrative:
General question: Results related to the intended outcome 2015Question: Summarise results related to the intended outcome (this information will be sent to Open Aid)Answer: Highlights from the reporting for 2015: • Memorandum of Understanding between Ministry of IDPs from Occupied Territories, Refugees and Accommodation (MRA), MOED and Public Registry Agency signed on transferring state owned common spaces to IDP condominiums in former collective centers. • Rehabilitation of Akhalsopeli former Boarding School building completed and 39 internally displaced person (IDP) families provided with durable housing. • 39 self-reliance grants (SRG) were delivered to IDPs who received durable housing in Akhalsopeli former Boarding School building. • Individial Business Grants (IBG) and Small and Medium Entreprize (SME) grants outcome monitoring exercises took place in West Georgia revealing positive grant impact on beneficiaries and their businesses. • 1300 IDPs received legal assistance. • Georgian Young Lawyer Association (GYLA) organized round table discussions on IDP's housing rights and on IDP Ministry Steering Committee’s Challenges. • Danish Refugee Council (DRC) together with Public Defender’s Office organized three meetings between MRA and local NGOs as a part of its feedback mechanism to the MRA. • 11 houses constructed with UNHCR and SIDA funding in previous years were registered in Public Registry Agency with DRC lawyers’ assistance. It was impossible to register additional 12 houses due to various legal problems. In total during the course of the project DRC assisted 41 families in registering their houses in Public Registry Agency. • Legal aid service satisfaction survey revealed that the level of IDP satisfaction with legal aid service is extremely high (99%).
Summary of overall results: • 39 IDP families have been offered accommodation in rehabilitated apartments. • The development and implementation of a functional and transparent selection process for IDP families selected by the MRA to recieve accomodation, which led to fewer complaints. • A total of 217 livelyhood grants were delivered to vulnerable families to support income generating activities. • 123 jobs have been created 50% for IDPs and 50% for local population • The job creation, livelyhood grants and small business grants have led to a clear income increase in the targeted families. • 9 815 beneficieries have recieved inidividual legal consultations during the programme and 810 group conultations were carried out. The satisfaction rate of the individual consultations were 99%. • Several rounds of meeting were organized between local and NGOs and the MRA to discuss IDP issues. • 500 direct beneficiaries use renovated facilities for education (pre-school and school) purposes in target communities in Abkhazia. • 10 community projects were carried out (6 in village kindergartens, 2 in village schools and 2 in Pirveli Galis village House of Culture). All projects are financially sustainable through funding from the local de facto authorities except the House of Culture which is dependent of voluntary contributions and community participation. • 855 youth participated in youth development training 75 of these were additionally given a training of trainers course. • A multi-ethnic theatre group was developed and in 2014, 300 persons attended public performances by the youth leaders on stage. • 33 businesses, with 48 entrepreneurs, recieved financial support in Abkhazia. At the end of the programme 29 businesses remained fully operational. 86% of the entrepreneurs have states that the grants from DRC allowed them to expand geografically or attract new clients. In most cases the DRC grants made a difference at product level either in terms of quality, design och change in the nature of the product sold.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
